Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wavelet Analysis of Periodic Error for Improved Displacement Metrology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will enable new fundamental research into displacement measuring interferometry. In the heterodyne, or two-frequency, systems to be studied here, the phase shift in laser light of one frequency reflected from a moving target relative to laser light of a second frequency reflected from a fixed target is used to determine displacement in applications requiring sub-nanometer positioning accuracy. The objective of the research is to apply wavelet analysis techniques to characterize periodic error, which is caused by mixing of the two light frequencies and leads to non-cumulative positioning errors on the order of several nanometers. Wavelets provide a new approach to signal analysis for periodic error; they have previously been used in image compression, voice recognition, and medical applications. The use of wavelets, rather than the more traditional Fourier transform approach, is required because periodic error varies with time under non-constant velocity conditions. Additionally, the error amplitude is time-varying when polarization-maintaining fibers are used to deliver the laser light to the interferometer optics. This is a common occurrence because it is generally desired to isolate the heat-generating laser source from the measurement platform.

If successful, this research will enable improved metrology capabilities and, subsequently, new technological advancements in the nano-science field. This research promises to improve the measurement technique (displacement measuring interferometry) that offers the highest performance in terms of accuracy, resolution, and range. This transducer is critical to the semiconductor manufacturing industry, for example, where it is used in a feedback control system to position the silicon wafer relative to the lithographic optics. One limitation on the achievable linewidth (and, ultimately, the chip processing speed) is the stage positioning accuracy. Other applications include transducer calibration and machines for material removal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this research is to improve displacement measuring metrology by compensating periodic errors in heterodyne interferometry. Much of the literature on calibration and metrology using heterodyne interferometry focuses on quasi-static motions. The goal of this work is to expand the knowledge base for heterodyne interferometry metrology during dynamic applications. As such, this research investigated the use wavelets to identify and compensate periodic errors during non-constant velocity motions and for time-varying amplitude periodic errors.

As a result of this project, the investigators were able to successfully compensate periodic errors in both simulated and experimental constant and non-constant velocity motion using complex wavelet analysis. Moreover, the investigators simulated errors from dynamic Doppler frequency shifts and investigated compensation algorithms to correct this error in real-time. Periodic error amplitudes can be compensated to below 1 nm. Simulations demonstrated a reduction in displacement error from 100+ nm to <3 nm for Doppler frequency shifts in a ±15 kHz Doppler frequency band. We have also investigated a simple real-time algorithm using Kalman filters to compare the periodic error correction between this method and the wavelet method.

This research has resulted in new knowledge leading to a robust algorithm capable of compensating periodic error in real-time; and a robust algorithm for compensating dynamic Doppler frequency shift errors in the measured displacement in real-time. Results have been disseminated through 7 publications and a project web site.

The knowledge generated from this project can be used to significantly enhance measurement accuracy during dynamic motions for heterodyne interferometry systems leading to higher quality motion trajectories for precision systems sucha. This project has provided opportunities for students to fabricate experimental test setups and collect data, perform fundamental research on advanced signal processing and filtering, create and optimize novel algorithms, disseminate research results during conferences, and begin writing an invention disclosure to be submitted for a patent application.
